Result.Abstract: Dissociative fugue was first treated as a distinct psychiatric illness in Bordeaux in 1887, and was taken up by Charcot as automatisme ambulatoire in 1888. Charcot held that fugue episodes were caused by latent epilepsy; his opponents maintained an hysterical origin. The diagnosis flourished in France for more than a decade but, like the superordinate diagnosis of hysteria, had faded

Result.Title: Linguistically invariant inductive logic

Result.Abstract: Philosophers have been referring to the "Kripke-Putnam" theory of natural- kind terms for over 30 years.
